Coverage remained the same at 98.163% when pulling **c957082186672a9779ca60e66421c7c07eb44908 on shvmsnju:regexp-to-cucumberexp** into **16901cdc336b58bf78d0403378713c6c090dfafd on cucumber:main**.

Hi @mattwynne, in the cli.steps.ts file in step-definitions, 
when i try to change  When(  /^I run cucumber-js \(installed (locally|globally)\)$/ ........
to When('I run cucumber-js \(installed (locally|globally))' it is showing linting problem (no-useless-escapes) 
How do we change this kind of regexp to cucumber expressions

> Hi @mattwynne, in the cli.steps.ts file in step-definitions,
> when i try to change When( /^I run cucumber-js (installed (locally|globally))$/ ........
> to When('I run cucumber-js (installed (locally|globally))' it is showing linting problem (no-useless-escapes)
> How do we change this kind of regexp to cucumber expressions

I'm not sure actually!

I would have thought that something [like this](https://cucumber.github.io/cucumber-expressions/?advanced=1&expression=I%20run%20cucumber-js%20%5C%28installed%20locally%2Fglobally%5C%29&step=I%20run%20cucumber-js%20installed%20locally) would work:

* you need to escape the parentheses as `\(` and `\)\, because in Cucumber Expressions they mean the text is optional, but you want them to be interpreted literally.
* you can use a `/` to indicate that either `locally` or `globally` is a good value

I think this might have thrown up a slight bug in cucumber-expressions, but we can work around it.

If you look at [the step definition](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/main/features/step_definitions/cli_steps.ts#L83) it just has a big `if` statement around it anyway, so I'd just split this into two step definitions each with a hard-coded `locally` or `globally`.

> If you look at [the step definition](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/main/features/step_definitions/cli_steps.ts#L83) it just has a big if statement around it anyway, so I'd just split this into two step definitions each with a hard-coded locally or globally.

+1 I think this is the cleanest way.

@shvmsnju since this stands as a good change on its own, I'll merge it in and you can deal with [this issue](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1926#issuecomment-1045963883) in a separate PR, OK?

> @shvmsnju since this stands as a good change on its own, I'll merge it in and you can deal with [this issue](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1926#issuecomment-1045963883) in a separate PR, OK?

@mattwynne yes of course! I was just a busy with work so i was not able to do that untill now. Will try to do that during this weekend!

Hi @mattwynne,

Even if we break the step definition into two parts, When we implement the step definition like: 

When('I run cucumber-js \(installed locally\)',{ 

Eslint will not allow escaping the bracket using \ as we don't need it in regular string and eslint considers this as a useless escape character and removes it when we save the file. To escape the bracket so that it is considered as a literal bracket and not optional text in cucumber expression we need to escape the \ character before the bracket using another \. I guess the whole thing sounds pretty confusing but you will understand when u see the code. I ran the tests and they are passing.

body: Instead of having a try/catch around this function just have it return an optional error message.
comments:
[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/46759506/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/46759506)

Coverage decreased (-0.002%) to 98.163% when pulling **8c8bd8270b844e7a694920f48111b6b4f8fea995 on no-exceptions-for-flow-control** into **7099a6a5055ef33bb0dd5e0343264b7118e6c7e1 on main**.
I did consider using a promise as a kind of Maybe object, so the calling code could do something like

```javascript
validateNodeEngineVersion(process.version).catch(errorMessage => {
  console.error(error) // eslint-disable-line no-console
  process.exit(1)
})
```

Still using exceptions for flow control really, but perhaps it reads better?

Another alternative would be to pass the assertion function a callback to run if the engine is invalid, like:

```javascript
validateNodeEngineVersion(process.version, errorMessage => {
  console.error(error) // eslint-disable-line no-console
  process.exit(1)
})
```

That way the conditional stays inside the function. That's probably my favourite of them all.
@mattwynne I quite like the callback idea there.

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>tj/commander.js</summary>

### [`v9.0.0`](https://togithub.com/tj/commander.js/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#​900-2022-01-28)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/tj/commander.js/compare/v8.3.0...v9.0.0)

##### Added

-   simpler ECMAScript import (\[[#​1589](https://togithub.com/tj/commander.js/issues/1589)])
-   Option.preset() allows specifying value/arg for option when used without option-argument (especially optional, but also boolean option) (\[[#​1652](https://togithub.com/tj/commander.js/issues/1652)])
-   `.executableDir()` for custom search for subcommands (\[[#​1571](https://togithub.com/tj/commander.js/issues/1571)])
-   throw with helpful message if pass `Option` to `.option()` or `.requiredOption()` (\[[#​1655](https://togithub.com/tj/commander.js/issues/1655)])
-   .`error()` for generating errors from client code just like Commander generated errors, with support for  `.configureOutput()`, `.exitOverride()`, and `.showHelpAfterError()` (\[[#​1675](https://togithub.com/tj/commander.js/issues/1675)])
-   `.optsWithGlobals()` to return merged local and global options (\[[#​1671](https://togithub.com/tj/commander.js/issues/1671)])

##### Changed

-   *Breaking:* Commander 9 requires Node.js v12.20.0 or higher
-   update package-lock.json to lockfile@2 format (\[[#​1659](https://togithub.com/tj/commander.js/issues/1659)])
-   `showSuggestionAfterError` is now on by default (\[[#​1657](https://togithub.com/tj/commander.js/issues/1657)])
-   *Breaking:* default value specified for boolean option now always used as default value (see .preset() to match some previous behaviours) (\[[#​1652](https://togithub.com/tj/commander.js/issues/1652)])
-   default value for boolean option only shown in help if true/false (\[[#​1652](https://togithub.com/tj/commander.js/issues/1652)])
-   use command name as prefix for subcommand stand-alone executable name (with fallback to script name for backwards compatibility) (\[[#​1571](https://togithub.com/tj/commander.js/issues/1571)])
-   allow absolute path with `executableFile` (\[[#​1571](https://togithub.com/tj/commander.js/issues/1571)])
-   removed restriction that nested subcommands must specify `executableFile` (\[[#​1571](https://togithub.com/tj/commander.js/issues/1571)])
-   TypeScript: allow passing readonly string array to `.choices()` \[([#​1667](https://togithub.com/tj/commander.js/issues/1667))]
-   TypeScript: allow passing readonly string array to `.parse()`, `.parseAsync()`, `.aliases()` \[([#​1669](https://togithub.com/tj/commander.js/issues/1669))]

##### Fixed

-   option with optional argument not supplied on command line now works when option already has a value, whether from default value or from previous arguments (\[[#​1652](https://togithub.com/tj/commander.js/issues/1652)])

##### Removed

-   *Breaking:* removed internal fallback to `require.main.filename` when script not known from arguments passed to `.parse()` (can supply details using `.name()`, and `.executableDir()` or `executableFile`) (\[[#​1571](https://togithub.com/tj/commander.js/issues/1571)])

</details>

| [chalk](https://togithub.com/chalk/chalk) | [`^4.1.2` -> `^5.0.0`](https://renovatebot.com/diffs/npm/chalk/4.1.2/5.0.0) | [![age](https://badges.renovateapi.com/packages/npm/chalk/5.0.0/age-slim)](https://docs.renovatebot.com/merge-confidence/) | [![adoption](https://badges.renovateapi.com/packages/npm/chalk/5.0.0/adoption-slim)](https://docs.renovatebot.com/merge-confidence/) | [![passing](https://badges.renovateapi.com/packages/npm/chalk/5.0.0/compatibility-slim/4.1.2)](https://docs.renovatebot.com/merge-confidence/) | [![confidence](https://badges.renovateapi.com/packages/npm/chalk/5.0.0/confidence-slim/4.1.2)](https://docs.renovatebot.com/merge-confidence/) |

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>chalk/chalk</summary>

### [`v5.0.0`](https://togithub.com/chalk/chalk/releases/v5.0.0)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/chalk/chalk/compare/v4.1.2...v5.0.0)

##### Breaking

-   **This package is now pure ESM. Please [read this](https://gist.github.com/sindresorhus/a39789f98801d908bbc7ff3ecc99d99c).**
    -   If you use TypeScript, you will want to stay on Chalk 4 until TypeScript 4.6 is out. [Why.](https://togithub.com/microsoft/TypeScript/issues/46452)
    -   If you use a bundler, make sure it supports ESM and that you have correctly configured it for ESM.
    -   The Chalk issue tracker is not a support channel for your favorite build/bundler tool.
    -   It's totally fine to stay on Chalk v4. It's been stable for years.
-   Require Node.js 12.20  [`fa16f4e`](https://togithub.com/chalk/chalk/commit/fa16f4e)
-   Move some properties off the default export to individual named exports:
    -   `chalk.Instance` ‚Üí `Chalk`
    -   `chalk.supportsColor` ‚Üí `supportsColor`
    -   `chalk.stderr` ‚Üí `chalkStderr`
    -   `chalk.stderr.supportsColor` ‚Üí `supportsColorStderr`
-   Remove `.keyword()`, `.hsl()`, `.hsv()`, `.hwb()`, and `.ansi()` coloring methods ([#​433](https://togithub.com/chalk/chalk/issues/433))  [`4cf2e40`](https://togithub.com/chalk/chalk/commit/4cf2e40)
    -   These were not commonly used and added a lot of bloat to Chalk. You can achieve the same by using the [`color-convert` package](https://togithub.com/Qix-/color-convert).
-   The tagged template literal support moved into a separate package: [`chalk-template`](https://togithub.com/chalk/chalk-template) ([#​524](https://togithub.com/chalk/chalk/issues/524))  [`c987c61`](https://togithub.com/chalk/chalk/commit/c987c61)

```diff
-import chalk from 'chalk';
+import chalkTemplate from 'chalk-template';

-chalk`2 + 3 = {bold ${2 + 3}}`;
+chalkTemplate`2 + 3 = {bold ${2 + 3}}`;
```

##### Improvements

-   Bundle dependencies  [`04fdbd6`](https://togithub.com/chalk/chalk/commit/04fdbd6)
    -   This means Chalk no longer has any dependencies üéâ
-   [The install size is less than half of v4.](https://packagephobia.com/result?p=chalk)
-   Add `overline` style  ([#​433](https://togithub.com/chalk/chalk/issues/433))  [`4cf2e40`](https://togithub.com/chalk/chalk/commit/4cf2e40)
-   Preserve function prototype methods ([#​434](https://togithub.com/chalk/chalk/issues/434))  [`0fba91b`](https://togithub.com/chalk/chalk/commit/0fba91b)

</details>

body:
# Description

Creates two versions of the npm release workflow - one for stable releases, and one for release candidates, based on branch naming patterns. The former are tagged as `latest` and the latter as `next`.

# Motivation & context

Unless a tag is specified, npm packages default to `latest` on publication. This meant that, when a release candidate was out, in practise users would run `npm install @cucumber/cucumber` and get the release candidate when we would want them to get the latest stable version unless they opt in to the RC.

`next` is a loose convention in the npm ecosystem for tagging prereleases. So next time there is an RC, regular users will still get the latest stable version when they install, and enthusiasts can do `npm install @cucumber/cucumber@next` to get the RC.

## Type of change

<!--- Delete any options that are not relevant -->

- Refactoring/debt (improvement to code design or tooling without changing behaviour)

# Checklist:

<!--- 
Go over all the following points, and put an `x` in all the boxes that apply. 
-->

- [x] I have read the [**CONTRIBUTING**](../CONTRIBUTING.md) document.
- [ ] My change needed additional tests
  - [ ] I have added tests to cover my changes.
- [ ] My change requires a change to the documentation.
  - [ ] I have updated the documentation accordingly.
- [ ] I have added an entry to the "Unreleased" section of the [**CHANGELOG**](../CHANGELOG.md), linking to this pull request.

Their most recently public accepted PR is: https://github.com/cucumber/action-publish-npm/pull/1

# Description

Updated the migration docs to include changing requirements for `setDefaultTimeout`.

# Motivation & context

Previously, a developer could call `setDefaultTimeout` inside step definitions, etc. The new documentation for timeouts says this is not possible and I've confirmed that.

## Type of change

- Documentation

# Checklist:

body:
# Description

Handle all permutations of exporting a custom formatter or snippet class from userland code, across ESM and CommonJS.

It's ugly but it works and has solid tests, and when we get to a point (probably in another 1-2 major releases) when we can go ESM only then most of the complexity can be removed.

Also, add a couple of missing things to the main export.

# Motivation & context

To prevent regression from current functionality as we switch from `require` to `import`. This was affecting the pretty formatter with the latest RC.

## Type of change

# Description

Switch from `colors` to [`chalk`](https://github.com/chalk/chalk) for terminal coloring (in our own code at least).

# Motivation & context

Fixes #1888.

Background:

- https://www.theverge.com/2022/1/9/22874949/developer-corrupts-open-source-libraries-projects-affected
- https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1885

Basically we need to move away from this package (and anything else by this author), and `chalk` has been better for a while anyway.

Note that some other packages we depend on still use colors:

```
$ npm why colors

colors@1.4.0
node_modules/colors
  optional colors@"1.4.0" from cli-table3@0.6.1
  node_modules/cli-table3
    cli-table3@"0.6.1" from the root project
  colors@"^1.0.3" from dependency-lint@7.1.0
  node_modules/dependency-lint
    dev dependency-lint@"7.1.0" from the root project
```

I'll raise upstream PRs for those when I can.

## Type of change

<!--- Delete any options that are not relevant -->

- Refactoring/debt (improvement to code design or tooling without changing behaviour)

body:
# Description

Use a more conventional place to store prettier config

# Motivation & context

So that VSCode's prettier plugin can automatically find it.

Currently, VSCode doesn't understand our prettier config, so the code formatter from the prettier plugin reformats the code using defaults (e.g. adding semi-colons), which then breaks the eslint rules!

## Type of change

- Refactoring/debt (improvement to code design or tooling without changing behaviour)

body:
# Description

Add a simple example project for people using TypeScript

# Motivation & context

We've heard from our users that they'd like more examples, and better documentation.

Today, someone asked on Slack about how to test a TypeScript project. Rather than explain it to them, I thought I'd show them an example.

I'm hoping we can add more of these, for other typical use-cases.

## Type of change

- Refactoring/debt (improvement to code design or tooling without changing behaviour)

# Questions / puzzles / feedback wanted

* Should we run this example as part of the CI build, to check for regressions?
* Should we reference the version of Cucumber in the project itself (i.e. use a relative `file://..` path in `package.json` or continue using a dependency on a stable / released version of Cucumber?
* Is there anything about this example that could be more exemplary, or could be removed to make it simpler?
* I've added the folder to the list of exclusions in `dependency-lint.yml` because it was giving an error - was that the right thing to do?
comments:
[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/46154507/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/46154507)

Coverage remained the same at 98.211% when pulling **cad41e6bddebc5b316c0adecdd2cd8721de99bbd on typescript-example** into **c34e20d5114b0c8ff4191be54adb4ebafac12697 on main**.

> I'm not totally sure but I'm tending towards wanting these examples in a separate repo so we don't have to uncouple them from the tooling in this project (linting etc as you've found). That repo could also serve as a list of community-sourced examples and templates e.g. https://github.com/davidjgoss/cucumber-puppeteer-typescript-starter (sorry for the plug).

Yep, that would work too. I guess I'm thinking about discover-ability by placing it here, but we could still have an `examples` folder in this repo that just contains a README linking out to other places.

Were you thinking one repo per example or one repo _of_ examples?

> Were you thinking one repo per example or one repo of examples?

Good question. I had been thinking one repo, but if we did them individually then they could be [template repos](https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-repositories/creating-a-template-repository) - not sure how commonly these would be used though.

> I guess I'm thinking about discover-ability by placing it here

On this point I think the list of examples should go in the readme, probably right below the `npm install` instructions, like "clone one of these examples and read on for the full docs" kind of thing. What do you think?
Should this go into https://github.com/cucumber-examples/ ?
I think that would work, with a link from the readme in this repo. Matt?

> Should this go into https://github.com/cucumber-examples/ ?

I didn't know about that org! (or at least if I did, I'd forgotten ü§≠)

Honestly, that feels a bit far away to me. I'd prefer them to be at least under the cucumber org for discover-ability, but I don't feel that strongly about it.
@aslakhellesoy do you know how come those example repos are not under the https://github.com/cucumber-school org? Aren't they used for in-person school trainings?

If we use one repo for all examples, I think that will make it more likely that we'll get community submissions (as they can be made via pull requests to that repo). I think that probably trumps the advantage of the template repo option, WDYT?

OK, I've moved it into https://github.com/cucumber-examples/cucumber-js-examples

We should probably think about how to have some kind of CI on that repo so that it doesn't rot.

Questions/actions before we close this PR:

* Should we move that repo under the cucumber org or is it fine where it is?
* Where are the places we should link to that examples repo so it's easily discover-able?

* I think "cucumber-examples" is a good place to look for examples how to use cucumber.
* One place in the docs to point to it could be an item/link on the https://cucumber.io/docs/guides/ page (because it is similar/related to the "10 Minute Tutorial").
Ok, it's now live here: https://github.com/cucumber-examples/cucumber-js-examples

I'm still wondering about where's the best place to put signposts so these are easy to discover.

I noticed we have https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/main/docs/nodejs_example.md linked from the README. Maybe we should change the README to just link to the examples repo and remove this page?

> @aslakhellesoy do you know how come those example repos are not under the https://github.com/cucumber-school org? Aren't they used for in-person school trainings?

IIRC it was @sebrose who created the `cucumber-examples` org. Seb, can you refresh our memory about why we didn‚Äôt just add more repos to the `cucumber-school` org instead?

> I'm still wondering about where's the best place to put signposts so these are easy to discover.
> 
> I noticed we have https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/main/docs/nodejs_example.md linked from the README. Maybe we should change the README to just link to the examples repo and remove this page?

üëç
A list of examples in the readme would be nice IMO
Starting point: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1918 - we could list the examples there individually or just link to the examples root, I don't feel strongly either way.

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>prettier/prettier</summary>

### [`v2.5.1`](https://togithub.com/prettier/prettier/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#​251)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/prettier/prettier/compare/2.5.0...2.5.1)

[diff](https://togithub.com/prettier/prettier/compare/2.5.0...2.5.1)

##### Improve formatting for empty tuple types ([#​11884](https://togithub.com/prettier/prettier/pull/11884) by [@​sosukesuzuki](https://togithub.com/sosukesuzuki))

<!-- prettier-ignore -->

```tsx
// Input
type Foo =
  Foooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo extends []
    ? Foo3
    : Foo4;

// Prettier 2.5.0
type Foo = Foooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo extends [

]
  ? Foo3
  : Foo4;

// Prettier 2.5.0 (tailingCommma = all)
// Invalid TypeScript code
type Foo = Foooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo extends [
  ,
]
  ? Foo3
  : Foo4;

// Prettier 2.5.1
type Foo =
  Foooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo extends []
    ? Foo3
    : Foo4;

```

##### Fix compatibility with Jest inline snapshot test ([#​11892](https://togithub.com/prettier/prettier/pull/11892) by [@​fisker](https://togithub.com/fisker))

A internal change in Prettier@v2.5.0 accidentally breaks the Jest inline snapshot test.

##### Support Glimmer's named blocks ([#​11899](https://togithub.com/prettier/prettier/pull/11899) by [@​duailibe](https://togithub.com/duailibe))

Prettier already supported this feature, but it converted empty named blocks to self-closing, which is not supported by the Glimmer compiler.

See: [Glimmer's named blocks](https://emberjs.github.io/rfcs/0460-yieldable-named-blocks.html).

<!-- prettier-ignore -->

```hbs
// Input
<Component>
  <:named></:named>
</Component>

// Prettier 2.5.0
<Component>
  <:named />
</Component>

// Prettier 2.5.1
<Component>
  <:named></:named>
</Component>
```

</details>

Coverage remained the same at 98.257% when pulling **7c5c016e129ea34d0c9332ab4be1c0b9b2475269 on export-package-json-again** into **42d95b6e7f256a6a660f09576190bfdd7665d608 on main**.

Do we keep that one: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1866?

I would keep it. I think exporting the version number can be useful. But this remain duplication so, what do you think?

> > I would keep it. I think exporting the version number can be useful. But this remain duplication so, what do you think?
> 
> No problem with having both from my side (this is the important one because of existing usage, but I think having an export for it makes sense too).
> 
> Also, could we add a test to prove this works? There is one here that covers the paths under `lib` that we could extend:
> 
> https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/main/features/direct_imports.feature#L48

I will merge the PR wich export the version as part of the API, then add a test in direct_imports.feature which will then cover both:
- the possibility to import the version number from the package.json
- the possibility to import the version number from the library

body:
# Description

Fixes. #1853 
With ESM support, the version number of cucumber-js is not as exposed as it was due to package.json not exported.
It seems more reliable with ESM to have version defined in a source file then exported by the libraries.

To keep the version sync with the one defined in package.json, the npm package [genversion](https://www.npmjs.com/package/genversion) has been used.

# Motivation & context

Pretty sure it may be useful with the incoming API too :)

## Type of change

<!--- Delete any options that are not relevant -->

I think we could consider this a breaking change: the way to find the version of cucumber programmatically has changed

- Breaking change (will cause existing functionality to not
  work as expected)

<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

# Description

* Add a try/catch block around a line in our `features/support` code that creates a symlink. If you're using Windows, unless you have enabled "Developer Mode" this line throws an error. We now catch the error and show a helpful message to the user.
* Replace uses of `cp` command (which is not available in a Windows PowerShell / `cmd.exe` prompt) with an equivalent `npx` command that will work cross-platform. 

# Motivation & context

* The features won't run if you don't have "Developer Mode" enabled. See #1852
* The `build-local` script won't run unless you have a `cp` command in your path.

Big thanks to @RukenaG for inspiring this change!

## Type of change

- Refactoring/debt (improvement to code design or tooling without changing behaviour)

# Description

Move the chapter about configuration file at the top of the doc to give it more visibility

# Motivation & context

The fact that the cucumber configuration file must remain a commonJs file is very important as without that, we may think the esm support is actually broken.

Moving the chapter back on top should give it more visibility.

body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

# Description

This adds the async `runCucumber` function for doing a test run programatically. It's not yet exposed publicly, but is used internally by the CCK tests.

This has involved:

- Pulling most of the guts out of the `Cli` class, since that is now a consumer of this new function
- Handling the i18n-related commands purely in the `cli` module
- Various other tweaks and refactors

# Motivation & context

First step towards #1711.

Now seems a good time to validate the approach on a few fronts:

- Defaulting of configuration options is generally moving _inwards_, so it's not tied to the argv parsing and so that API consumers can call with a very small signature if appropriate.
- The shape of the config object passed in to `runCucumber`. The idea is that the `support` block could be replaced with an existing support code library on subsequent runs in the same process, which solves a problem for a few framework authors.
- No breaking changes in the existing `Cli`, `Runtime` etc - framework authors are using these in the wild and we need to have a stable and compelling alternative before pulling them.

If we're happy and this goes in, the rest can follow quite quickly. Next steps:

- Implement the ability to reuse support code library
- Add a mechanism to load configuration from argv, files etc in a sane way
- Add integration tests specifically for this API
- Expose publicly (probably with an "experimental" qualifier), add documentation

## Type of change

<!--- Delete any options that are not relevant -->

- Refactoring/debt (improvement to code design or tooling without changing behaviour)
- New feature (non-breaking change which adds new behaviour)

# Checklist:

<!--- Go over all the following points, and put an `x` in all the boxes that apply. -->
<!--- If you're unsure about any of these, don't hesitate to ask. We're here to help! -->

- [x] I have read the [**CONTRIBUTING**](../CONTRIBUTING.md) document.
- [x] My code follows the code style of this project.
- [x] I have added tests to cover my changes.
- [ ] My change requires a change to the documentation.
- [ ] I have updated the documentation accordingly.
- [ ] I have added an entry to the "Unreleased" section of the [**CHANGELOG**](../CHANGELOG.md), linking to this pull request.

Coverage decreased (-0.04%) to 98.255% when pulling **9db9f615b74fdaf438c3f1452153e216f0e25a04 on api-poc** into **49a51f9532beb6474fc543158fe9f1986cb08ef1 on main**.

Great to see progress here! üòç

> The shape of the config object passed in to `runCucumber`. The idea is that the `support` block could be replaced with an existing support code library on subsequent runs in the same process, which solves a problem for a few framework authors.

Good to hear it is still on the radar. It will dramatically improve mutation testing performance ‚è©üí®
I can only offer nit-picks, this looks great to me!
Thanks for the feedback @aurelien-reeves @nicojs @mattwynne - I'm going to address Matt's very fair nit-pick, beef up the tests a bit and then get this merged and on to the next part.

Question: does this break the current (undocumented) API? 

This is what we're using in our cucumber plugin right now:

```ts
const argv = [
      'node',
      'cucumber-js',
      '--retry',
      '0',
      '--parallel',
      '0',
      '--format',
      require.resolve('./stryker-formatter'),
      ...bailArgs,
      ...tagsArgs,
      ...profileArgs,
      ...testFilterArgs,
    ];
    const cli = new Cli({
      argv,
      cwd: process.cwd(),
      stdout: process.stdout,
    });
   await cli.run();
```

> Question: does this break the current (undocumented) API?
> 
> This is what we're using in our cucumber plugin right now:
> 
> ```ts
> const argv = [
>       'node',
>       'cucumber-js',
>       '--retry',
>       '0',
>       '--parallel',
>       '0',
>       '--format',
>       require.resolve('./stryker-formatter'),
>       ...bailArgs,
>       ...tagsArgs,
>       ...profileArgs,
>       ...testFilterArgs,
>     ];
>     const cli = new Cli({
>       argv,
>       cwd: process.cwd(),
>       stdout: process.stdout,
>     });
>    await cli.run();
> ```

I took a look at the code in the branch. As far as I can tell, your snippet won't be broken. It will use the new API under the hood, but it will work as expected :)
@nicojs @aurelien-reeves yep, very much a conscious choice to avoid any breaking changes to existing Cli and Runtime for the near to mid term at least.

> Question: does this break the current (undocumented) API?

For the record: Yes.

[This](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1711#issuecomment-1042474677) is what we're using in our code that depends on cucumber right now and have done for the last 3-4 years.

@binarymist I don't think `getConfiguration` was intended to be public, it perhaps should have been a private method. I think I understand your use case though having looked through the code and this should be catered for via the new API in the next RC.

> this should be catered for via the new API in the next RC

Great!

Problme is... If we didn't use `getConfiguration`, then we wouldn't be able to show the _Build User_ (think end user) the test plan that they are about to run. Infact when we implemented this, the Cucumber CLI was barely usable. Quite a few of our large architectural decissions were made due to the fact that Cucumber just wouldn't do what we needed it to do easily.
commit_messages: api: add runCucumber function internally (#1849)

body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->
# Motivation & context
When the developer's parent directory had spaces in them, it caused the [absolute path scenario](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1845) in the formatter paths feature to fail. 

We discovered the scenario didn't work because it required quotations around the path to be read into the CLI properly since it had spaces in it. Otherwise, it would split the path into separate arguments as it's supposed to. We added quotes to the scenario to ensure the path was read as one argument but then we discovered that the underlying [cli index code](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/fd540c048a30a74328ed509b3f6b2ca1fe991f93/src/cli/index.ts#L115) couldn't cope with the path with quotes around them. 

We changed the configuration builder to clean up the quotes in the path before passing to the cli.

## Type of change

<!--- Delete any options that are not relevant -->

- Refactoring/debt (improvement to code design or tooling without changing behaviour)

# Checklist:

- [ ] I have added an entry to the "Unreleased" section of the [**CHANGELOG**](../CHANGELOG.md), linking to this pull request.

See this upstream PR which should resolve the conflict https://github.com/standard/eslint-config-standard-with-typescript/pull/702

At the moment, `eslint-plugin-promise` and `eslint-config-standard-with-typescript` are not yet compatible with eslint 8

This seems to be in progress for `eslint-plugin-promise`: https://github.com/xjamundx/eslint-plugin-promise/pull/219
and for `eslint-config-standard-with-typescript`: https://github.com/standard/eslint-config-standard-with-typescript/issues/728
@aurelien-reeves the standard one looks like it's heading for being unmaintained - it might be worth reevaluating whether we need it. Do we use it in the common ones?

@davidjgoss I have done some updates here:

- I have removed the eslint plugins which prevent the upgrade
- I have took some inspiration from [cucumber-expressions](https://github.com/cucumber/common/blob/main/package.json) for the configuration of eslint
- I had to deactivate some rules to make the build happy

Those rules were actually certainly already not applied. Later we may consider trying to turn those on and fix the code accordingly

What do you think?

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/45383915/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/45383915)

waiting ü§ì
Sorry I missed this @aurelien-reeves - looks good.

> Sorry I missed this @aurelien-reeves - looks good.

no problem, thank you!
commit_messages:
chore(deps): update eslint packages (major) (#1840)

* chore(deps): update eslint packages

* Update eslint configuration

- remove plugins which prevent upgrading eslint
- update the configuration based on the one from cucumber-expression
- update a piece of code to make linting happy

Note: some rules have been deactivated to make the update of eslint
possible without breaking our build. Those rules may be deactivated
later as part of dedicated pull requests.

* Activate eslint-plugin-simple-import-sort

* Add simple-import-sort to dependency-lint ignore list

* Revert "Add simple-import-sort to dependency-lint ignore list"

This reverts commit 1bd2f3212b3c9ddf666b11710c524a9fb4a2e36c.

* Revert "Activate eslint-plugin-simple-import-sort"

This reverts commit a0075e73cd735942e03cb99eda5b73c53a4eb31a.

* Remove eslint-plugin-simple-import-sort

Co-authored-by: Renovate Bot <bot@renovateapp.com>
Co-authored-by: aurelien-reeves <aurelien.reeves@smartbear.com>

</details>

<details>
<summary>import-js/eslint-plugin-import</summary>

### [`v2.25.2`](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​2252---2021-10-12)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/compare/v2.25.1...v2.25.2)

##### Fixed

-   \[Deps] update `eslint-module-utils` for real this time (\[[#​2255](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/issues/2255)])

### [`v2.25.1`](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​2251---2021-10-11)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/compare/v2.25.0...v2.25.1)

##### Fixed

-   \[Deps] update `eslint-module-utils`

### [`v2.25.0`](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​2250---2021-10-11)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/compare/v2.24.2...v2.25.0)

##### Added

-   Support `eslint` v8 (\[[#​2191](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/issues/2191)], thanks \[[@​ota-meshi](https://togithub.com/ota-meshi)])
-   \[`no-unresolved`]: add `caseSensitiveStrict` option (\[[#​1262](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/issues/1262)], thanks \[[@​sergei-startsev](https://togithub.com/sergei-startsev)])
-   \[`no-unused-modules`]: add eslint v8 support (\[[#​2194](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/issues/2194)], thanks \[[@​coderaiser](https://togithub.com/coderaiser)])
-   \[`no-restricted-paths`]: add/restore glob pattern support (\[[#​2219](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/issues/2219)], thanks \[[@​stropho](https://togithub.com/stropho)])
-   \[`no-unused-modules`]: support dynamic imports (\[[#​1660](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/issues/1660)], \[[#​2212](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/issues/2212)], thanks \[[@​maxkomarychev](https://togithub.com/maxkomarychev)], \[[@​aladdin-add](https://togithub.com/aladdin-add)], \[[@​Hypnosphi](https://togithub.com/Hypnosphi)])

##### Fixed

-   \[`no-unresolved`]: ignore type-only imports (\[[#​2220](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/issues/2220)], thanks \[[@​jablko](https://togithub.com/jablko)])
-   \[`order`]: fix sorting imports inside TypeScript module declarations (\[[#​2226](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/issues/2226)], thanks \[[@​remcohaszing](https://togithub.com/remcohaszing)])
-   \[`default`], `ExportMap`: Resolve extended TypeScript configuration files (\[[#​2240](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/issues/2240)], thanks \[[@​mrmckeb](https://togithub.com/mrmckeb)])

##### Changed

-   \[Refactor] switch to an internal replacement for `pkg-up` and `read-pkg-up` (\[[#​2047](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/issues/2047)], thanks \[[@​mgwalker](https://togithub.com/mgwalker)])
-   \[patch] TypeScript config: remove `.d.ts` from \[`import/parsers` setting] and \[`import/extensions` setting] (\[[#​2220](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/issues/2220)], thanks \[[@​jablko](https://togithub.com/jablko)])
-   \[Refactor] \[`no-unresolved`], \[`no-extraneous-dependencies`]: moduleVisitor usage (\[[#​2233](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/issues/2233)], thanks \[[@​jablko](https://togithub.com/jablko)])

</details>

<details>
<summary>xjamundx/eslint-plugin-promise</summary>

### [`v5.1.1`](https://togithub.com/xjamundx/eslint-plugin-promise/compare/v5.1.0...v5.1.1)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/xjamundx/eslint-plugin-promise/compare/v5.1.0...v5.1.1)

</details>

### [`v10.4.0`](https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/releases/v10.4.0)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/compare/v10.3.1...v10.4.0)

**Added**

-   Adds support for targets "es2020" and "es2021" to swc transpiler ([#​1521](https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1521))
-   Adds automatic target downgrade when using older versions of swc ([#​1521](https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1521))
    -   If tsconfig specifies es2020, but your version of swc only supports up to es2019, ts-node will automatically switch to es2019 instead of throwing an error

**Changed**

-   Improves types and API docs for `creatEsmHooks` ([API docs](https://typestrong.org/ts-node/api/index.html#createEsmHooks)) ([#​1506](https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1506), [#​1529](https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1529))

**Fixed**

-   Fix [#​1526](https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1526): data URL handling in new ESM loader hooks API ([#​1526](https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1526), [#​1529](https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1529))

body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

# Description

* Replaced stacktrace-js with stackChain
* Fixed line number mapping problem in stackChain using "@cspotcode/source-map-support"
* 2 tests still failing, intend to fix these before submitting PR

# Motivation & context

Tried to work with cucumber-js on my machine. The tests kept breaking since I had parentheses in my parent directory.

Fixes #1735 

## Type of change

<!--- Delete any options that are not relevant -->

- Refactoring/debt (improvement to code design or tooling without changing behaviour)
- Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

_Remember to add an entry to the relevant section of CHANGELOG.md as part of this pull request._

## Note to other contributors

None

## Update required of cucumber.io/docs

None

# Checklist:

<!--- Go over all the following points, and put an `x` in all the boxes that apply. -->
<!--- If you're unsure about any of these, don't hesitate to ask. We're here to help! -->

- [x] I have read the [**CONTRIBUTING**](../CONTRIBUTING.md) document.
- [x] My code follows the code style of this project.
- [x] I have added tests to cover my changes.
- [x] My change requires a change to the documentation.
- [x] I have updated the documentation accordingly.
- [x] I have added an entry to the "Unreleased" section of the [**CHANGELOG**](../CHANGELOG.md), linking to this pull request.
comments: We have a [failing test on Windows](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/runs/3978130458?check_suite_focus=true) because the path slashes are the wrong way around. @davidjgoss is there any precedent for dealing with this kind of thing?

@eoola I figured it would be clearer for others to read this PR if the initial refactoring I did to break out the `getDefinitionLineAndUri` function was already done and not part of this change. So I made #1826 with those changes, and I've just merged it in.

Can you fetch `main` again and merge it into your branch and push?
I've merged main into the branch. Let me know if there's anything else you'd like me to do.

Thanks @eoola that diff looks much easier to read now.

I notice the checks are failing at the `npm install` step - I wonder if, now that the merge is done, you need to run `npm install` again and check in / push the `package-lock.json` file. Can you give that a try?
I actually ran npm install before pushing because I noticed the package.json file was different.
That's better! Now we can see the test failures again.

@charlierudolph @davidjgoss @aurelien-reeves I have a question about [this scenario](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/main/features/custom_stack_trace.feature) which is the [last one failing](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/runs/4071832892?check_suite_focus=true) in this PR.

It looks to me like the scenario was intended to cover [this try/catch statement](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/fec9841b92f903ad562a06274179d4a13a19e9df/src/support_code_library_builder/get_definition_line_and_uri.ts#L29) which no longer seems to be hit in this scenario. From what I can see, the user is now able to override `Error.prepareStackTrace` without it causing us any issues when we try to dig into stack traces ourselves. üéâ

I wonder if, now that we've moved away from using `stacktrace.js`, the whole thing is redundant?  I'm tempted to recommend we remove the try/catch statement (which would simplify this function a lot) and remove the scenario too.

What are your thoughts? Did I miss something?

@eoola we should remove the `.DS_Store` file from this PR.

I've just pushed a [change to `main` to add it in `.gitignore`](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/commit/0322b84dc76e76bf306cfc4af160d6f8f3f5ee14) which should stop this from happening again, but I think you'll still need to `git rm .DS_Store` and then push another commit to your branch to remove it from the PR.

To get this to green (i.e. all the checks are passing) @eoola, we could remove [the assertion step](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/main/features/custom_stack_trace.feature#L24-L27) from the failing scenario for now (oh, and [fix the Windows thing](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1824#discussion_r740464569)).

Getting the tests passing probably give us a better platform to have a discussion about what to do with that scenario.

Can you take care of those two changes?

@eoola thanks for sticking with this!

@mattwynne agree it seems particular to that library, no strong feelings about removing.

> To get this to green (i.e. all the checks are passing) @eoola, we could remove [the assertion step](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/main/features/custom_stack_trace.feature#L24-L27) from the failing scenario for now (oh, and [fix the Windows thing](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1824#discussion_r740464569)).
> 
> Getting the tests passing probably give us a better platform to have a discussion about what to do with that scenario.
> 
> Can you take care of those two changes?

Would you like me to remove the highlighted code from the actual test and push that?

> Would you like me to remove the highlighted code from the actual test and push that?

Yes, let's start with that.

body:
# Description

Format `CHANGELOG.md` with https://github.com/cucumber/changelog and fix tag links with https://gist.github.com/aslakhellesoy/878599eb55fabfe8452c1128001c38eb

# Motivation & context

The `cucumber` organization is gradually streamlining the release process to use GitHub Actions and a set of standard commands, as documented in [RELEASING.md](https://github.com/cucumber/.github/blob/main/RELEASING.md).

We use the `changelog` command to update `CHANGELOG.md`. This tool first parses the `CHANGELOG.md` into an internal representations and then pretty-prints it. The tool expects the file to only use the 5 categories used by the [keepachangelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/) spec, so several of the non-standard headers have been modified manually.

The tool also expects contents to *only* be bullets (no code examples or indented bullets). I have de-indented nested bullets and removed code examples. If we need these in the future, we should add this to a separate `UPGRADING.md` file. (There are many of these at GitHub - here is one: https://github.com/Level/level-test/blob/master/UPGRADING.md)

<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

# Description

Don't use `import` - and instead fall back to `require` - if the file extension is not a native JavaScript one (meaning `import` would not be able to handle it in any case).

# Motivation & context

Generally when using a transpiler, it's activated via `--require-module` which we then use as a heuristic to use `require` instead of `import` - however users sometimes just have their transpiler setup in a file that is `--require`'d - e.g. when passing a custom tsconfig to ts-node.

## Type of change

<!--- Delete any options that are not relevant -->

- Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

# Description

When deciding if a test case's worst status should represent a failure, just bail if we're in dry run, since we never want to fail.

# Motivation & context

`--dry-run` should not cause the process to exit with a failure if there are undefined or ambiguous steps - that should only happen if we're trying to do a real test run.

Fixes #1768.

## Type of change

<!--- Delete any options that are not relevant -->

- Refactoring/debt (improvement to code design or tooling without changing behaviour)
- Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

_Remember to add an entry to the relevant section of CHANGELOG.md as part of this pull request._

body:
# Description

Following on from #1699, refactor the documentation for formatters to:

- Provide more context and detail
- Show examples of output (including GIFs for terminal stuff and screenshot for HTML)
- Split out targeted guides for snippets and rerun

Also, since we're here, align the way we load custom snippet syntaxes with how we load custom formatters, which better enables third-party packages and Yarn PnP (fixes #1640).

Probably best reviewed by viewing the new markdown docs on the branch:

- https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/docs-rework-formatters/docs/formatters.md
- https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/docs-rework-formatters/docs/rerun.md
- https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/docs-rework-formatters/docs/snippets.md

# Motivation & context

From #1699:

> - The CLI page is very long and not easy to find information in.
> - Many useful features are only mentioned briefly.
> - Some closely-related topics aren't documented together (e.g. `World` and `--world-parameters`)
> - We don't really have a "Getting Started" guide
> 
> This series of PRs aims to split out most of the content from the CLI page into targeted articles with examples and add a "Getting Started" guide. [AVA](https://github.com/avajs/ava) is one project that does this well (see "Recipes" in their README).

## Type of change

<!--- Delete any options that are not relevant -->

- Refactoring/debt (improvement to code design or tooling without changing behaviour)
- Breaking change (will cause existing functionality to not
  work as expected)

Changelog entry added for the breaking change in the code. Docs changes will be announced in release notes for 8.0.0.

## Note to other contributors

Next up will be the readme, it's long overdue some love.

body:
# Description

- Remove the CLI option for `--predictable-ids` and related plumbing
- Make changes to fixture-based tests to ignore fields that will change on every run, as we do in the CCK tests (reusing the same list of keys)

# Motivation & context

We added predictable timestamps and identifiers at a time where we envisaged checking these values in the CCK so that all implementations would behave the same in this regard.

In practise, that level of parity was not practically achievable and so we now exclude timestamps and identifiers when validating against the CCK. Therefore it makes sense to remove this option and related complexity in the codebase.

## Type of change

- Refactoring/debt (improvement to code design or tooling without changing behaviour)

(Technically a breaking change but there would be no sense in using this option except for our own testing. At any rate, it's going to be in a major version bump anyway.)

# Checklist:

- [x] My code follows the code style of this project.
- [ ] My change requires a change to the documentation.
- [ ] I have updated the documentation accordingly.
- [x] I have read the [**CONTRIBUTING**](../CONTRIBUTING.md) document.
- [x] I have added tests to cover my changes.
- [x] All new and existing tests passed.

# Description

Adds the `Rule` keyword to those we output localised versions of via the `--i18n-keywords <LANG>` option.

# Motivation & context

Completeness.

Note that we don't need to add `Example` because it's a synonym of `Scenario` and thus already handled.

- Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

body:
# Description
As it currently stands, when running the command  cucumber.js --help, the formatters do not show up.
To remedy this situation, it was suggested to do the following:

- Refactor getConstructorByType method to hold a Record<string, typeof Formatter>
- Add a documentation field to Formatter class to hold the static string
- Use the Record in argv_parser.ts to print out all the formatters

# Motivation & context
Fixes #1700 

## Type of change
- Refactoring/debt (improvement to code design or tooling without changing behaviour)
- Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

## Note to other contributors


## Update required of cucumber.io/docs
No update needed

# Checklist:

- [X] My code follows the code style of this project.
- [ ] My change requires a change to the documentation.
- [ ] I have updated the documentation accordingly.
- [X] I have read the [**CONTRIBUTING**](../CONTRIBUTING.md) document.
- [ ] I have added tests to cover my changes.
- [ ] All new and existing tests passed.
comments: @aurelien-reeves, this is still a WIP. I just wanted to get your feedback if I am in the right direction.

> @aurelien-reeves, this is still a WIP. I just wanted to get your feedback if I am in the right direction.

So, feel free to set this PR as a draft. You can do that on the right panel just under the "reviewers" section.

And if you could fix the linting issues as I explained before, that will help to review your code :)

From your changes, I cannot see what breaks the tests.

To reproduce on your computer, you can run `npm run unit-test`
If you have trouble debugging those failures, feel free to ask, I'll investigate on my side ;)

Coverage increased (+0.008%) to 98.289% when pulling **58dc26f014a975361f72ab102c2162a5315f2350 on TomerPacific:feature/list-formatters-in-help-command-1700** into **0aeb59c61ef2dfcd332c0efeaf229252c328b12e on cucumber:main**.

Great! That's a good starting point!

Are you confident for the next steps?

@aurelien-reeves , I wouldn't say confident, but I am trying the best I can.
I have committed several more changes and I would like to explain them for clarity and to get feedback.

- I have created a new class called **FormatterDocumentationHelper** which holds the string literals that should appear in the cli
- For some of the choices, I do not know what should appear and I have left them blank on purpose
- To allow the Formatter constructor to set this field (documentation), I have altered the **IFormatterOptions** interface
- I have done all of this, since the type is not passed to the constructor and I tried finding an elegant solution to overcome this problem

I realize that there may be better suited options for this or your intent with this feature might be in an opposite direction and that is why I am reaching out. I have run the linter and the unit tests after my commits.

> 
> 
> @aurelien-reeves , I wouldn't say confident, but I am trying the best I can.

Don't worry! Your contribution is very appreciated, and the review process is there for communication and conversation üòä

> I have committed several more changes and I would like to explain them for clarity and to get feedback.
> 
>     * I have created a new class called **FormatterDocumentationHelper** which holds the string literals that should appear in the cli
> 
>     * For some of the choices, I do not know what should appear and I have left them blank on purpose

I think you are pretty close to what @aslakhellesoy suggested üëå
I would just change the `documentation` property for formatters from a dynamic property which is set by the contructor with a static "hard-coded" property, something like the following:

```typescript
export default class JsonFormatter extends Formatter {
  public static readonly documentation = "Prints the feature as JSON. The JSON format is in maintenance mode. Please consider using the message formatter with the standalone json-formatter (https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/tree/master/json-formatter)."
  // ...
}
```

That way the documentation is attached to the formatter itself, not at runtime but within the source code. Easy to find, it may even be a reminder for developers. Less code is involved. We would just had to make sure the `documentation` property is part of the base `Formatter` class for all formatter being compatible.

Nice :+1: 

Next steps would be to:
- extract the record you have created in ` src/formatter/builder.ts` into a way it would be usable from anywhere else
- update `src/cli/argv_parser.ts` to use the record with the `--format` option using the `choices` method from `commander`: https://github.com/tj/commander.js#more-configuration
- build a documentation string using the documentation from all formatters and use it with the `--format` option as well

:)

I think we need to be careful with `.choices()` if it (as it looks from the commander docs) disallows any other entries than the ones in the list, since we support custom formatters with a package name or path so that could be any string really. Definitely worth an experiment though!

@aurelien-reeves , I'm looking into adding the different formatters using the `choices` attribute, and I need some guidance.

- I have seen in the command docs, that the use of the choices option is allowed on an `Option `object.
`.addOption(new Option('-d, --drink <size>', 'drink size').choices(['small', 'medium', 'large']))`
- The way things are built in the argv_parser class is different since it uses the` .option` way which does not have a choices method

I wanted to know what is the preferred way here, since all the options are written in a specific way and I do not want to break from the style and guide. I might also be missing something, even though I went over the commander classes themselves.

Current:
```
.option(
        '--format-options <JSON>',
        'provide options for formatters (repeatable)',
        ArgvParser.mergeJson('--format-options'),
        {}
      )
```

Future:
```
.addOption(
        new Option(
          '--format-options <JSON>', 
          'provide options for formatters (repeatable)'
          ).choices([])
      ) // this will need to call the ArgvParser.mergeJson method as well
```

> 
> 
> @aurelien-reeves , I'm looking into adding the different formatters using the `choices` attribute, and I need some guidance.
> 

Actually, as @davidjgoss noticed, this is not a good idea. So we won't use choices, but just add a proper documentation to the `--format` option

So what you did until then is still pretty relevant, and will be usefull to build a nice documentation to `--format`

- Snippets

```
  -d, --dry-run                    invoke formatters without executing steps (default: false)
  --exit                           force shutdown of the event loop when the test run has finished: cucumber will call process.exit (default: false)
  --fail-fast                      abort the run on first failure (default: false)
  -f, --format <TYPE[:PATH]>       specify the output format, optionally supply PATH to redirect formatter output (repeatable).  Available formats:
      json: Prints the feature as JSON. The JSON format is in maintenance mode. Please consider using the message formatter with the standalone json-formatter (https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/tree/master/j
son-formatter).
      message: Outputs protobuf messages
      html: Outputs HTML report
      progress: Prints one character per scenario.
      progress-bar: Similar to the Progress Formatter, but provides a real-time updating progress bar based on the total number of steps to be executed in the test run
      rerun: Prints failing files with line numbers.
      snippets: The Snippets Formatter doesn't output anything regarding the test run; it just prints snippets to implement any undefined steps
      summary: Summary output of feature and scenarios
      usage: Prints where step definitions are used. The slowest step definitions (with duration) are listed first. If --dry-run is used the duration is not shown, and step definitions are sorted by filename in
stead.
      usage-json: Does what the Usage Formatter does, but outputs JSON, which can be output to a file and then consumed by other tools.
   (default: [])
  --format-options <JSON>          provide options for formatters (repeatable) (default: {})
  --i18n-keywords <ISO 639-1>      list language keywords (default: "")
  --i18n-languages                 list languages (default: false)
  --language <ISO 639-1>           provide the default language for feature files (default: "en")
  --name <REGEXP>                  only execute the scenarios with name matching the expression (repeatable) (default: [])
  --no-strict                      succeed even if there are pending steps
  --order <TYPE[:SEED]>            run scenarios in the specified order. Type should be `defined` or `random` (default: "defined")
  -p, --profile <NAME>             specify the profile to use (repeatable) (default: [])
  --parallel <NUMBER_OF_WORKERS>   run in parallel with the given number of workers (default: 0)
  --publish                        Publish a report to https://reports.cucumber.io (default: false)
  --publish-quiet                  Don't print information banner about publishing reports (default: false)
  -r, --require <GLOB|DIR|FILE>    require files before executing features (repeatable) (default: [])
  --require-module <NODE_MODULE>   require node modules before requiring files (repeatable) (default: [])
  --retry <NUMBER_OF_RETRIES>      specify the number of times to retry failing test cases (default: 0) (default: 0)
  --retry-tag-filter <EXPRESSION>  only retries the features or scenarios with tags matching the expression (repeatable).
          This option requires '--retry' to be specified. (default: "")
  -t, --tags <EXPRESSION>          only execute the features or scenarios with tags matching the expression (repeatable) (default: "")
  --world-parameters <JSON>        provide parameters that will be passed to the world constructor (repeatable) (default: {})
  -h, --help                       display help for command
  For more details please visit https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/master/docs/cli.md

```

Is this PR ready to not be a draft?

Oh, I forgot: an entry in the changelog is missing! Could you add one @TomerPacific?

Once it is done I'll merge it
@aurelien-reeves, I added the feature to the changelog. Let me know if it is ok.
Great, thanks :)
@aurelien-reeves, I just want to say again how much I appreciate your guidance, patience and help throughout this. I am sure it wasn't exactly easy on your end.
@TomerPacific it was a real pleasure! I am glad that you reach the end of that PR without being discouraged üòÄ

body:
This reverts commit a2dcce6a45dd20bf7a52def5ea9b5f4a3743a642.

<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

# Description

As discussed at our last community meeting, we may need to discuss the removal of setDefinitionFunctionWrapper if we cannot find a workaround to help folks from webdriver.io: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1772
comments:
[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/43249550/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/43249550)

Coverage increased (+0.01%) to 98.28% when pulling **fbe97375d55d3d068ce3d5314feb04f589671b36 on revert-drop-of-setdefinitionfunctionwrapper** into **f2007762d00f1ac597527cb083f7afaf169a34b2 on main**.

I agree we have cause for re-adding this but I wonder if we could reimagine it slightly as we do, especially since it'll be in a major release anyway. Some thoughts:

- The pushback has been around people wanting to just do extra stuff around the step (cucumber-ruby calls this `AroundStep` I think) and has nothing to do with generators - could the stuff about generator step definitions still be removed?
- Related to above, would `AroundStep` be more intuitive name for this?
- One shortcoming with how this works now is the wrapper fn is applied to the step code in place, which is then run as normal. This means e.g. you could hit the step timeout in your wrapper, which is no help if your wrapper intends to mitigate timeouts and/or [instrument retries](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1772). Could we shift it up a bit so the wrapper and the step code aren't just squished together?

cc @charlierudolph @aslakhellesoy

> I agree we have cause for re-adding this but I wonder if we could reimagine it slightly as we do, especially since it'll be in a major release anyway. 

Agreed!

> Some thoughts:
>     * The pushback has been around people wanting to just do extra stuff around the step (cucumber-ruby calls this `AroundStep` I think) and has nothing to do with generators - could the stuff about generator step definitions still be removed?

Yes, I guess so.
Indeed we may try to just re-implement it without generators.

In Ruby, this is just `Around` and it is around a whole scenario, not a step.
And we don't like it that much and discourage its usage in favor of `Before` and `After`.

> 
>     * Related to above, would `AroundStep` be more intuitive name for this?
> 

I think we may keep the word "wrap" to help users to know it is related to what was existing before.
`WrapStep` or something like that?

I'd prefer not to add this back. If we really just need an `AroundStep`, I don't understand why BeforeStep / AfterStep is not sufficient and I would think those hooks can be used to accomplish the same thing.

> 
> 
> I'd prefer not to add this back. If we really just need an `AroundStep`, I don't understand why BeforeStep / AfterStep is not sufficient and I would think those hooks can be used to accomplish the same thing.

Agreed, as long as we are able to help users into migrating their code

It is like `Around` in cucumber-ruby: we don't like it, we would like to remove it, but that would be too painful for our users, so we discourage it, but we keep it for the moment. We may finally remove it, but it won't be done too quickly.

As @davidjgoss suggested: we could try to implement it without generators and with less and cleaner code
Thoughts on closing this for now and we can discuss more on #1772?
I would suggest to keep it open at least just as a reminder that we should not release right now before having found a proper solution to this

Small update to remove support for generators, and thus the dependencies to bluebird and is-generator packages.
I've updated the migration guide accordingly, but actually I am not sure I am right üòÖ

Anyone to review it?
@aurelien-reeves sounds good, I'll take a look.
@davidjgoss I have made some changes after your review. Does it look better now?
Thanks @davidjgoss!
@davidjgoss @charlierudolph @aslakhellesoy any strong objection into merging this?
Aside from my one comment about the wording in changelog / migration guide, looks good to me

body:
# Description
I was working on a[ custom formatter for `pickled-cucumber` ](https://github.com/muralco/pickled-cucumber/blob/master/src/formatter/profile-jsonl.ts) and noticed that fast tests always reported 0 as the duration, after some debugging I noticed that we were not using the most accurate clock, so I changed it for `performance.now` from perf hooks
https://nodejs.org/api/perf_hooks.html#perf_hooks_performance_now
As a side effect, that seems to be a monotonic clock, making the
measurements not affected by leap seconds

# Motivation & context

The durations numbers reported by cucumber were not accurate.

## Type of change

- Refactoring/debt (improvement to code design or tooling without changing behaviour)

# Checklist:
- [x] My code follows the code style of this project.
- [x] My change requires a change to the documentation.
- [x] I have updated the documentation accordingly.
- [x] I have read the [**CONTRIBUTING**](../CONTRIBUTING.md) document.
- [x] I have added tests to cover my changes.
- [x] All new and existing tests passed.
comments: Test are failing due to inaccurate `nanos`, It will be really hard to fix those tests, due to the jitter we can expect between test runs. I will need some help here. :pray:

For the tests, we are using https://github.com/sinonjs/fake-timers to have predictable timestamps.
sinonjs/fake-timers can fake performance.now, but only in browser. So we may need to find an alternative.
@aurelien-reeves will research a bit about alternatives to fix that, thanks!
@joac I've found a way, please check my previous message

I had to increase the colum size for durations in msecs on usage formatter tests, due to bigger numbers being reported, do you think is ok @aurelien-reeves o we should use `Math.round` or `Math.floor ` on the formatter itself?

Seems that the tests that break are not using the fake timers. I don't understand well the initialization process of the test suite :cry:

> Seems that the tests that break are not using the fake timers. I don't understand well the initialization process of the test suite üò¢

You do not have to force push a single commit each time.
Actually that prevent us to see the history of the CI.

> 
> 
> I had to increase the colum size for durations in msecs on usage formatter tests, due to bigger numbers being reported, do you think is ok @aurelien-reeves o we should use `Math.round` or `Math.floor ` on the formatter itself?

I think that technically, it looks good to me. And I like your enhancement.
But I would wait for the opinion of @davidjgoss, @charlierudolph or @aslakhellesoy about it as I am still relatively new on the project, I may miss some edge cases here üòÖ.

I think you should revert your changes on ` features/support/hooks.ts`
It seems to be responsible for the CI being stuck

> But as I said, I prefer to wait for some more experienced folks to review it before approving it. I don't know if using the monotonic performance clock could have some undesirable impact somewhere with the reports.

As long as the measurement unit is the same (milliseconds I presume) I have no objections. Using a monotonic clock is the correct way to measure duration in any software system (using a wall clock is always wrong).

> I had to increase the colum size for durations in msecs on usage formatter tests

Do we have an example of how this comes out?

>

@aurelien-reeves thanks for posting - I think the durations look a little noisy there, it would benefit from maybe limiting to 2 or 3 decimal places in the formatter, but I don't think it's a huge deal.

> @aurelien-reeves thanks for posting - I think the durations look a little noisy there, it would benefit from maybe limiting to 2 or 3 decimal places in the formatter, but I don't think it's a huge deal.

@davidjgoss Do you think that we should address that on this PR or a separate one?.

> As long as the measurement unit is the same (milliseconds I presume) I have no objections. Using a monotonic clock is the correct way to measure duration in any software system (using a wall clock is always wrong).

@aslakhellesoy  [From node the documentation](https://nodejs.org/api/perf_hooks.html#perf_hooks_performance_now): 
_Returns the current high resolution millisecond timestamp, where 0 represents the start of the current node process._
It didn't say anything about being monotonic, but [the implementation](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/lib/internal/perf/utils.js#L13) uses `process.hrtime()` [that claims](https://nodejs.org/api/process.html#process_process_hrtime_time) _These times are relative to an arbitrary time in the past, and not related to the time of day and therefore not subject to clock drift._ From that, I understand that is a monotonic clock.
@joac if you have time to do on this PR that‚Äôs be great!
@davidjgoss It's done!

Hi @joac,

Thanks for your making your first contribution to Cucumber, and welcome to the Cucumber committers team! You can now push directly to this repo and all other repos under the cucumber organization! üçæ

In return for this generous offer we hope you will:

* ‚úÖ Continue to use branches and pull requests. When someone on the core team approves a pull request (yours or someone else's), you're welcome to merge it yourself.
* üíö Commit to setting a good example by following and upholding our [code of conduct](https://cucumber.io/conduct) in your interactions with other collaborators and users.
* üí¨ Join the [community Slack channel](http://cucumber.io/support#slack) to meet the rest of the team and make yourself at home.
* ‚ÑπÔ∏è Don't feel obliged to help, just do what you can if you have the time and the energy.
* üôã Ask if you need anything. We're looking for feedback about how to make the project more welcoming, so please tell us!

On behalf of the Cucumber core team,
Aslak Helles√∏y
Creator of Cucumber

Node. You must use at least ESLint v7.28.0, Prettier v2.0.0 and Node v12.0.0.

-   Use `context.getPhysicalFilename()` when available (ESLint 7.28+) (\[[#​2160](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/issues/2160)], thanks \[[@​pmcelhaney](https://togithub.com/pmcelhaney)])
-   \[`extensions`]/`importType`: fix isScoped treating @​/abc as scoped module (\[[#​2146](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/issues/2146)], thanks \[[@​rperello](https://togithub.com/rperello)])

##### Changed

-   \[Docs] \[`extensions`]: removed incorrect cases (\[[#​2138](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/issues/2138)], thanks \[[@​wenfangdu](https://togithub.com/wenfangdu)])
-   \[Tests] \[`order`]: add tests for `pathGroupsExcludedImportTypes: ['type']` (\[[#​2158](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/issues/2158)], thanks \[[@​atav32](https://togithub.com/atav32)])
-   \[Docs] \[`order`]:  improve the documentation for the `pathGroupsExcludedImportTypes` option (\[[#​2156](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/issues/2156)], thanks \[[@​liby](https://togithub.com/liby)])
-   \[Tests] \[`no-cycle`]: Restructure test files (\[[#​1517](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/issues/1517)], thanks \[[@​soryy708](https://togithub.com/soryy708)])
-   \[Docs] add description how to use plugin with yarn berry (\[[#​2179](https://togithub.com/import-js/eslint-plugin-import/issues/2179)], thanks \[[@​KostyaZgara](https://togithub.com/KostyaZgara)])

<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

# Description
Add time into interface `IJsonFeature` to can received actual test run time

# Motivation & context
I try to generate a report site from JSON file and I need time running test of feature files to sort which run first


## Type of change

<!--- Delete any options that are not relevant -->
- Refactoring/debt (improvement to code design or tooling without changing behaviour)
[_Remember to add an entry to the relevant section of CHANGELOG.md as part of this pull request._](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1784/commits/cc3d979d419fd275e72c59a95261f1d8cc3cb044#diff-06572a96a58dc510037d5efa622f9bec8519bc1beab13c9f251e97e657a9d4edL1849-R1851)

## Note to other contributors
- No impact

## Update required of cucumber.io/docs
- No impact

# Checklist:

<!--- Go over all the following points, and put an `x` in all the boxes that apply. -->
<!--- If you're unsure about any of these, don't hesitate to ask. We're here to help! -->

- [x] My code follows the code style of this project.
- [ ] My change requires a change to the documentation.
- [ ] I have updated the documentation accordingly.
- [x] I have read the [**CONTRIBUTING**](../CONTRIBUTING.md) document.
- [x] I have added tests to cover my changes.
- [x] All new and existing tests passed.
comments:
Hi,

Thanks for your contribution.

> I try to generate a report site from JSON file and I need time running test of feature files to sort which run first

Is this your only need? If so, please note that reports shows the test in the execution order. You don't need extra data to deduce that.

I encourage you to use your own custom formatter based on the internal formatters rather than extending the internal json formatter.

Also, did you take a look on the "messages" formatter? The json formatter is legacy. The "messages" are more modern and may be more efficient to process.

> I encourage you to use your own custom formatter based on the internal formatters rather than extending the internal json formatter.

Thanks for replying @aurelien-reeves 

Hi we already building a report side based on JSON fomatter and using random order option. So team want to add more information about timming to help metric and monitoring test cases better.

This help too much for comparing with logs in Backend site and tracking time between setup steps

> Hi we already building a report side based on JSON fomatter and using random order option. So team want to add more information about timming to help metric and monitoring test cases better.
> 
> This help too much for comparing with logs in Backend site and tracking time between setup steps

Ok. Thanks for the details.
Still, I think it will be better for you to extend the JSON formatter into a dedicated custom formatter with the info you need. Also we have put the JSON formatter into maintenance mode: we may not accept enhancement for that formatter.

I am not sure we will accept your pull request as it would impact everyone to covers your specific needs. With a custom formatter, you'll be free to do whatever you want, and to use it with your reporting service.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/42532527/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/42532527)

Coverage remained the same at 98.247% when pulling **a92fe6b97a76e0c0819c9c13c3a3a0bdc1631ce5 on vctqs1:main** into **1ecfcfe80c4cea17cbf17f9a4a14b3ad64b2b952 on cucumber:main**.

> Ok. Thanks for the details.
> Still, I think it will be better for you to extend the JSON formatter into a dedicated custom formatter with the info you need. Also we have put the JSON formatter into maintenance mode: we may not accept enhancement for that formatter.
> 
> I am not sure we will accept your pull request as it would impact everyone to covers your specific needs. With a custom formatter, you'll be free to do whatever you want, and to use it with your reporting service.


Thanks for your point out, But can I  ask why JSON formatter is legacy.

My team can write a custom formatter extends from JSON formatter but better if we can know reason why JSON formatter is legacy

Because all cucumber implementation did not had the same json structure. So a new common protocol has been created: messages.

Messages can be reported as ndjson, and that protocol is shared across all implementations. Some tooling exists to convert ndjson messages into a json that looks pretty close to the legacy json formatters.

At first we wanted to totally deprecate the json formatters. But as so many users are relying on it, we will keep it, but letting it in maintenance mode.

Also, messages do have all the timing data you need. Please give it a try. To get messages, use `--format message`

json formatter can be nice to share with humans.
But the message formatter will be better to work with when interacting with other programming tools. Here's the documentation for messages: https://github.com/cucumber/common/blob/main/messages/messages.md

@vctqs1 did you had the opportunity to take a look on the "message" formatter for your project?

I think the "message" formatter may better fit your needs.

> @vctqs1 did you had the opportunity to take a look on the "message" formatter for your project?
> 
> I think the "message" formatter may better fit your needs.

My team's trying to convert to message formatter. THANKS for your support. Hope I can contribute next time .

I'll close this PR. Many thanks again

Thanks @vctqs1 for your contribution, that was helpful in any case!

If you encounter any issue with the messages, please feel free to ask! Are you already on the cucumber community slack? If not, you can register for an account here: https://cucumberbdd-slack-invite.herokuapp.com/. You'll find plenty of help there :)
