body:
More or less copied the approach from [cucumber-jvm](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/tree/master/compatibility).

To run:

```
$ yarn
$ yarn cck-test
```

(Or, run `compatibility/cck_spec.ts` from your IDE.)

Done:

- Expose `World` and `IWorldOptions` in public API
- Add a `log` function to the World which attaches text with the cucumber log media type
- Emit attachments in new structure
- Add some methods to `DataTable`
- Emit `Meta` message at start of run - fixes #1310 
- Keep a stopwatch of the test run, use it for a `timestamp` on various messages
- Emit messages for hooks and step definitions
- Emit messages for parameter type definitions
- `stepMatchArgumentsLists` are now being emitted within `testCase.testSteps`
- `pickleAccepted` and `pickleRejected` messages are now not emitted
- `testCaseFinished.testResult` is now not emitted (see https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/issues/902)
- `testRunFinished.success` is now not emitted

Questions:

- `testCase` messages per CCK fixtures should be emitted together at start of run, rather than before each test case is started (non-trivial refactor - do we need this right away?)

body:
I noticed that the demo site is linked without https and doesn't have a redirect in place. That seemed worth fixing.

I went through the rest of the project looking for other links that could be improved:
* to add https
* where the ultimate site was different (e.g. paths changed or needed a www subdomain)
* where the websites were no longer responding:
  * jbpros.net is offline
  * simondean.org is a placeholder cpanel page

The last 2 items are the most worth attention, I think.
commit_messages: Using https where possible. Removing offline sites. (#1305)

body:
The duration (which was already in nanoseconds) was being multiplied by 1000000 in src/formatter/json_formatter.js. This lead to the duration being reported in femtoseconds instead of nanoseconds, as it was in Cucumber 5.x. I'm not sure why this addition was added, but, this PR fixes the behaviour and returns the duration to the previously correct value.

EDIT: as noted below, this error was introduced in 6.0.0, which changed the internal reporting from milliseconds to nanoseconds. The JSON formatter was not updated when the change happened.

Fixes #1256
commit_messages: json formatter: remove incorrect duration multiplication (#1257)

body:
When interrogating the `supportCodeLibrary` for producing a usage formatter or (in my case) documentation for all your steps, there is the `code` property on each `stepDefinition`, the value of which is the actual function you passed to `defineStep` or one of its aliases. This can then be printed, or run through a parser, etc.

However, if you use `setDefinitionFunctionWrapper`, that `code` is replaced by the generated wrapper function, which being just a delegate is not much use to look at or parse.

With this change, when applying a definition function wrapper, we preserve the original function on a new property `unwrappedCode` so it can be referenced if needed. I also updated the usage helper to reflect this.
commit_messages: usage: account for code wrapping (#1234)

The lowest version(s) of `glob` allowed to be used as a dependency for cucumber does not create absolute paths on my setup, despite `absolute: true` on this line: https://github.com/hypesystem/cucumber-js/blob/master/src/cli/configuration_builder.js#L75

I think the fix may have been https://github.com/isaacs/node-glob/pull/303. At least, setting the version to `^7.1.3` fixes the issue on my setup.

To avoid the issue for other people, I suggest upping the version of `glob` üòÑ

I noticed that `--fail-fast` gets slow on big projects.

It appears that this is a result of instantiating `CucumberExpression` instances too many times: once per test of whether the text of a step matches a given step definition (instead of once per _creation_ of that step definition).

This refactoring creates the expression (either a `CucumberExpression` or a `RegularExpression`) once per step definition, during the `finalize()` phase of building the support code library.

The result is much faster `--fail-fast` on large projects.

For example, on my current project, when the first step (of 1103 steps) fails:

Before:
```
> time ./node_modules/.bin/cucumber-js --fail-fast
./node_modules/.bin/cucumber-js --fail-fast  10.24s user 0.37s system 102% cpu 10.342 total
```

After:
```
> time ./node_modules/.bin/cucumber-js --fail-fast
./node_modules/.bin/cucumber-js --fail-fast  2.36s user 0.28s system 109% cpu 2.429 total
```

I also noticed that the various subclasses of `StepDefinition` actually had different properties and methods, so I extracted a `Definition` superclass to isolate the actual commonality.

This branch fixes wrong spawning of slave processes on Windows when running cucumber-js with `--parallel` flag

[Issue-1087](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1087)

This branch implements the CLI `--retry` flag to immediately re-run a failing scenario. 
If omitted the flag defaults to 0 (no retry logic).

A positive number will cause the `test_case_runner` to re-run its scenario up to the specified number of times if the previous run ended with `result.status === Status.FAILED`.
Any different result will immediately pass through (either the test case succeeded or it was marked as skipped or ambiguous).

That means the retry logic applies only to genuine failures of the scenario.

From the event protocol point of view the `test-step-started` event will be emitted for retrial steps as well, so the console will print more `.` than the actual length of the scenario, when retrying.

On the other hand, the `test-case-started` and `test-case-finished` events will be emitted just once (even if the test case has been retried).
This ensure flaky test cases won't appear more than once in formatter outputs (like the JSON one), thus affecting the total count of test cases reported per scenario/suite. Only the last run of test will be logged.
Arrow functions are fine to use as callbacks normally, so long as you understand how they work.

body:
My step definitions use different implementations of a common "user interface adapter" abstraction in Given/When/Then steps. You can see a rough example of this idea in the [todo-subsecond repo](https://github.com/subsecondtdd/todo-subsecond/blob/master/features/step_definitions/todo_steps.js).

I would like to enforce a strict separation of `given` steps talking directly to the domain model, versus `when` and `then` steps interacting with user interfaces.

However, because `Given`, `When` and `Then` are synonyms of `defineStep`, I cannot distinguish between these different steps in `setDefinitionFunctionWrapper`.

So this change adds a "phase" property to the `StepDefinition` model, which is then exposed as an additional argument to the `setDefinitionFunctionWrapper` helper. I'm not sure `phase` is the right name, what do you think?

If there is an alternative way of achieving what I'm after, I'd be happy to hear it!

It took me a while to figure out why the console was still printing colors even though I disabled them through "--format-options", but I figured out that's because "false" is parsed as true if used as string in JSON. Correct usage: --format-options '{"colorsEnabled": false}'

Hello there,

This should fix the ie11 support issue (https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1011). Finding a solution was kind of tricky, but it seems to work in my test environment and on the browser example.

- I added babelify `global` option. I used `only` section of `.babelrc` to limit its action to the problem node_modules.
- I had to add babel-polyfill to make Symbols work. I did try to use core-js/fn/Symbol instead (lighter solution), but I could not make it work.
- I had to manually register bluebird promises to remove some errors triggered on IE11.

It may be interesting to switch to native promises and to use babel 7 with the env preset. It would greatly simplify the babel stage.

This is a new take on #745, taking the ideas from #865 and incorporating them into the core rather than building a wrapper around it.

You can try it out with:

    ./bin/cucumber-js --pure functional-spike

In `--pure` mode, all step definitions take an extra `state` parameter as the first parameter preceding any parameters from Gherkin. The `state` parameter is passed the return value from the previous step definition or hook.

body:
Thought I'd take a crack at #746 while I was dealing with `:` splitting for the formatters. The compiler isn't as easy to unit test as the formatters was since the result of the split is used internally to the config builder plus it actually `require`s the module so you can't just send anything you want to it...like a windows absolute path. So I added an `OptionSplitter` utility that both the `--format` and `--compiler` can use. There are no new tests for `--compiler` because of the reason above, but the existing [feature](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/master/features/compiler.feature) should ensure there are no regressions.

The splitting itself almost turned out to be simple with negative look aheads and look behinds until I found out that js regex doesn't support look behinds. That's why there's still a little bit of logic to smash those back together.

When duration was added to this project it was noted that it needed to be in nanoseconds. See comment by aslakhellesoy [here](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/125)

The reason I really want to make this change is that the duration ends up being represented as 0ms in reporting tools as the unit is too small

body:
We sometimes want to use cucumber with features that haven't been released.

Adding `"cucumber": "cucumber/cucumber#some-branch"` to `package.json` will cause npm/yarn to pull from git, but it will *not* run babel over the files.

To make this work I've created a script that builds cucumber (if it's not already built), and trigger this in `postinstall`. I've also changed `prepublish` to use this script, to prevent babel from running twice.

This technique is already used in cucumber-expressions, and has been working nicely.

I needed this fix to get protractor support for cucumber 3.

  - Moved the invalid path scenario that was in `multiple_formattters.feature` to a new `formatter_paths.feature` so all the path related scenarios were together.
  - Added mustache to get the temp dir into the feature. ~~Added a new `replaceContextVariables` helper so that I could get the actual temp dir into the feature itself. It felt kind of hacky, but I didn't know of another way besides duplicating step definitions to deal with absolute paths explicitly.~~

body:
Commander by default throws an error when unexpected command-line option is present which is a problem when you try to pass additional arguments to the tests without specifying a 'command' but 'options' only, i.e. when using a profile.

For example the following works fine with `test/foo` and additional `--debug`:

    node node_modules/cucumber/bin/cucumber.js test/foo --require test/foo --debug

However the following throws an error `error: unknown option '--debug'` because `test/foo` directory is in profile definition:

    node node_modules/cucumber/bin/cucumber.js --profile foo --debug

The PR is to prevent Commander throwing exceptions when unexpected option is present and pass it verbatim to the tests.

This PR upgrades to [Cucumber Expressions 4.0.0](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/cucumber-expressions/CHANGELOG.md#400---2017-06-27)

There are backwards incompatible changes in this release, which might warrant a major version bump in cucumber-js too:

## Parameter types must be defined

Using an `{undefined}` parameter type will result in an error. This may sound like a hassle, but the benefits outweigh the drawbacks in my opinion.

Forcing users to define parameter types encourages the evolution of a ubiquitous language.

## New `{word}` and `{string}` parameter types

The `{word}` type is handy to use instead of old `{undefined}` ones.
The `{string}` type replaces the old `{stringInDoubleQuotes}` one, and works with both single and double quotes

## Parameter types can use the same regex

This used to cause errors in previous releases. Because they are now allowed, each undefined step
can result in several possible cucumber expressions for snippets, as outlined in https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/issues/132.

For this reason, the `CucumberExpressionGenerator.generateExpression` method is deprecated in favour of `CucumberExpressionGenerator.generateExpressions`, which returns a list of `GeneratedExpression` (the one at index 0 is the one the user is most likely to want).

So before this PR is merged, it should be updated to use the new method, and display all expressions when printing snippets. As discussed with @charlierudolph at cukeup, we're not sure how to best do that. Let's discuss some possible output examples in this issue before proceeding.

body:
It would be helpful to have the options available in the wrapper.
Then I can do something like this:

```javascript
defineSupportCode(function ({setDefinitionFunctionWrapper}) {
    setDefinitionFunctionWrapper(function (fn, options) {
        let retryTest = isFinite(options.retry) ? parseInt(options.retry, 10) : 0
        let wrappedFunction = isAsync(fn) || config.sync === false
            ? wrapStepAsync(fn, retryTest) : wrapStepSync(fn, retryTest)
        return wrappedFunction
    })
})
```

I'm currently writing a "wdio-cucumber2-framework" (which is a wrapper around cucumber 2 to allow webdriverio runner run cucumber tests), and this is the cleanest way for me to implement retrying (this is how it was done in wdio-cucumber-framework as well , with the options)

Please let me know what you think, I hope you don't feel like this is too much of a feature creep. :-) 

Thanks!

body:
Allow direct import of support code:

```javascript
const { 
  Given,
  When,
  Then,
  Before,
  After,
  defineParameterType, 
  addTransform, 
  defineStep, 
  registerHandler, 
  registerListener, 
  setDefaultTimeout, 
  setDefinitionFunctionWrapper, 
  setWorldConstructor 
} = require('cucumber');
```

Todo:
- [ ] Decide if we're keeping the `defineSupportCode`
- [ ] Update all feature files (or write new ones, if we decide to keep `defineSupportCode`)
- [ ] Update all docs (or add to the existing docs of we decide to keep `defineSupportCode`)

I personally think that its better to not export `defineSupportCode` from `cucumber` anymore. It will simplify the docs and features. I know there will initially be a pain for existing code that would need to be rewritten, but it will be much simpler in the end.

Note: related PR #828 was my first attempt.

Fixes issue #770

Make it possible to do this:

```javascript
const {given, when, then} = require('cucumber');
```

This is a work in progress.

I've hacked in the functionality without (hopefully) breaking the `const { defineSupportCode } = require('cucumber');` construct. However i think this solution gets a bit messy.
1. It can get complicated for an end user if you have multiple ways of doing things.
2. It gets complicated in the code, especially in the `support_code_fns.js` and `helpers.js`. 

If we drop the support for `defineSupportCode` we can cleanup the code further and simplify a lot of things INHO. For example, we can simplify the `support_code_libary/helpers.js`, `support_code_library/builder.js` and `support_code_fns.js`.  Also it would be possible to import all the functions like `addTransform`, `defineParameterType`, `registerHandler`, `registerListener`, `setDefaultTimeout`, `    setDefinitionFunctionWrapper`and `setWorldConstructor` directly from `'cucumber'`, which would simplify the usage even further.

Do you agree on this approach? It would mean rewriting the examples and test feature files.

Note: I haven't been able to run the features locally because of #826 

Fixes #770

body:
This PR resolves https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/792.
Currently returning a rejected promise from the BeforeFeatures hook will cause the run to:
- Exit with code=0 (expected=1).
- Throw a node unhandled rejection error.

The whole idea of the [webdriver control flow](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/wiki/WebDriverJs) is that asynchronous tasks can be written in a synchronous way, implicitly executing each promise when the one queued before is fullfiled.

This style mix very well with cucumber.js and should be encouraged. All that is needed is to return the last promise at the end of a step.
Backported to work on 1.3.1

supported format -  `key / type / value`.

example:
```
   Given an escaped prisoner:
     | name     | String | Monster Joe |
     | escapes  | Int    | 7           |
     | address  | String | Balfur 413  |
     | district | String | Sohoy       |
     | city     | String | London      |
     | caught   | Bool   | No          |
     | lastSeen | Date   | 1976-06-07  |
```

In step definition:
```
Given(/an escaped prisoner/g, function(dt, next) {
  const props = dt.map(); /* --> returns
    { 
      name:      "Monster Joe",
      escapes:   7,
      address:   "Balfur 413",
      district:  "Sohoy",
      city:      "London",
      caught:    false,
      lastSeen:  new Date("1976-06-07")
    }
  */
  this.prisoner = new Prisoner(props);
  next()
})
```

Will also work on a wider type support (Array, JSON, ...).

body:
When an asynchronous test step returns a promise rejected with an `Error` (`AssertionError` in the case of Chai), such as:

``` javascript
return expect(browser.getTitle()).to.eventually.equal('my website')
```

Cucumber produces the following error output:

```
/Users/jan/project/node_modules/cucumber/lib/cucumber/runtime/stack_trace_filter.js:9
  var fileName = frame.getFileName() || '';
                      ^
TypeError: node_modules/protractor-cucumber-framework/lib/resultsCapturer.js:60 Cannot read property 'getFileName' of undefined
    at isFrameInCucumber (/Users/jan/project/node_modules/cucumber/lib/cucumber/runtime/stack_trace_filter.js:9:23)
    at Array.<anonymous> (/Users/jan/project/node_modules/cucumber/lib/cucumber/runtime/stack_trace_filter.js:15:9)
    at TraceModifier._modify (/Users/jan/project/node_modules/cucumber/node_modules/stack-chain/stack-chain.js:44:32)
    at Function.prepareStackTrace (/Users/jan/project/node_modules/cucumber/node_modules/stack-chain/stack-chain.js:119:25)
    at /Users/jan/project/node_modules/protractor-cucumber-framework/lib/resultsCapturer.js:73:37
    at Object.run (/Users/jan/project/node_modules/cucumber/lib/cucumber/util/run.js:34:19)
    at Object.hear (/Users/jan/project/node_modules/cucumber/lib/cucumber/listener.js:15:23)
    at /Users/jan/project/node_modules/cucumber/lib/cucumber/runtime/event_broadcaster.js:28:18
    at iterate (/Users/jan/project/node_modules/cucumber/lib/cucumber/util/async_for_each.js:7:7)
    at nextTickCallbackWith0Args (node.js:420:9)
```

This is caused by an assumption made in the `stack_trace_filterer` that an instance of an `Error` will always have a stack trace associated with it.

This pull request adds a check to verify that the stack trace is not empty.
commit_messages: prevent error when stack trace has no frames

body:
Hey guys,

I tried following the [tagged hooks](https://github.com/MrSenko/cucumber-js#tagged-hooks) example from the documentation but I got:

```
/Users/krasimir/Work/TrialReach/projects/gargantua/node_modules/cucumber/lib/cucumber/tag_group_parser.js:4
      var splitTags = tagGroupString.split(TagGroupParser.TAG_SEPARATOR);
```

It looks like in `lib/cucumber/tag_group_parser.js` `tagGroupString` is actually not a string anymore. It comes as an object in the shape of:

```
{ tags: [ '@regression' ] }
```

So I added a simple check to transform that object into a string.

Cucumber and Cucumber.js are names and should therefore be uppercased.

This PR has 2 pieces:
1. Add rerun formatter so, at the end of test it will log the failed scenarios alone (this could be saved to a text file)
2. Run the failed scenarios by reading the text file which has the failed scenarios log

Run test using rerun formatter:
As of now cucumber does not support saving the logs to a file, till then its a way to simulate how to use it.

> node bin/cucumber.js features/cli.feature -f rerun > rerun.txt

Run failed scenarios by reading the text file:
When any argument passed starts with '@' then it will take it as input file and read the content before executing the scenarios

> node bin/cucumber.js @rerun.txt


Hi.
This Pull Request is to see if this feature is acceptable for the main project before I start refining it and cleaning up the tests.
## Purpose

This is designed to make the file system layout and arrangement of features
more flexible. Target audience is larger projects with multiple
developers.

Changes:
- Throws errors if more than one step definition matches a feature step.
- Small fixes for file path matching in Windows.
- **Special tag format for selecting which files are used for steps.**

The special tags are designed to be used where the `-r` tag is specified.
They should work where file name matching is done, but will be less
useful.
## Tags

If no source tags are set, default behaviour is used: all matching step
definitions will be used to fulfil a step.

If one or more file source tags are set in a file, then only the
specified sources are used. Sources accumulate, so each tag ADDS to the
available pool of definitions.

Tags are inherited, so setting at a feature level sets for all
scenarios.

Specific named file tags don't use path or `.js` ending. Files with the
matching name will be allowed as step definitions:

```
@:MySteps
```

Will match (e.g.)

```
./step_definitions/MySteps.js
./step_definitions/specific/path/MySteps.js
```

Directory path tags match against the end of the step files' path.
This is non-recursive, so child directories will not be used.

```
@./Interpretation
```

Will match

```
./step_definition/Interpretation/x.js
./step_definition/Interpretation/y.js
```

 ./step_definition/deeper/Interpretation/x.js

But not

```
./step_definition/Interpretation/deeper/y.js
```

Any steps loaded from {step path}/support/ will be included
regardless of tags
## Example feature file using the tags

``` cucumber
@./DataAccess
Feature: we need a local data store that persists incoming catalog data.
  We should be able to query the most recent data stored.
  We should be able to delete the entire data store ready for a refresh
  Data should not be modifiable once written.

  Scenario: storing data
    Given a running database instance
    And a DAL connected to it
    When I call to the DAL to store object data for an entity
    Then the call should complete with no errors

  @:DeleteEnabled_steps
  Scenario: deleting data
    Given a running database instance
    And a DAL connected to it
    When I call to the DAL to delete all data
    Then the call should complete with no errors
```

This fixes #249.  Buffers are not converted to strings using `buffer.toString('binary')` instead of `buffer.toString()`.  `buffer.toString()` defaults to `utf8` which broken any non-ASCII characters.  

This pull request also includes a fix for an issue in features/attachments.feature that meant the node.js version wasn't detected correctly and meant that streams weren't being tested in the feature file (they were still being tested in the specs).

Refer https://github.com/angular/protractor/issues/876#issuecomment-57892972.¬†
Prefer using the domain error handler instead of the top level Cucumber uses the top level uncaught error handler to catch exceptions
caught by tests.  Refer commit
https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/commit/9091129df4866cf705fb4ea7fb488f81e7cb96c2
and issue #51.  A good approach would be to wrap the test code
executions in try/catch blocks and use that exception instead of the
`uncaughtException` handler.  Another approach is to use the error
handler of a nodejs domain instead of the top level global
uncaughtException handler.  In this commit, I'm using the domain level
error handler approach.

The current implementation does not do a global reg ex replace for string step definitions.. This means the maximum number of placeholders could be 1 quoted dollar placeholder and 1 dollar placeholder. You couldn't have 2 dollar placeholders. 

For example the following would happen..

```
'I have "$btnA" and "$btnB" buttons
-> ^I have "([^"]*)" and "(.*)"$ (still works by coincidence)
```

And...

```
'I have $countA accounts and $countB projects' 
-> ^I have (.*) accounts and $countB projects$ 
```

@jbpros this pull request changes the behaviour of Scenario Outlines.  Scenario outlines are no longer present in the AST once the parsing has finished.  I.e. the scenario outlines are removed from the AST features when they are converted into scenarios.  The other way to have solved, these issues would have been something like changing the AstTreeWalker to not visit scenario outlines.  Which way to fix it do you think is best?  It would be good to know whether the Ruby and JVM ports of cucumber include the scenario outlines in the AST.  One thing that makes me wonder is that cucumber-jvm already includes the backgrounds in the AST.  

Because the scenario outlines are no longer in the AST, you no longer see them reported by the formatters/listenders.

This is a fix for #233.  It fixes two things: 
- The embeddings are no longer under the results.  The embeddings are now side-by-side with the results.  
- Text embeddings are now base64 encoded.

We're recording Selenium based tests and use this to compute time offsets to skip around in our screen recordings.

Currently there is no easy method to get an _absolute_ time from Cucumber output. The only approach is to see when Cucumber starts/terminates and subtract `duration` properties from that time. This is skewed by various other things (for example browser starting up before the first step gets executed).

Summing up `duration` is quite a hassle, and can be easily circumvented by this patch. This is just a hack, and does not pass tests. Please help me finding the correct way to implement such a timestamp.

As consequence of the [Issue#230](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/230) I found an error in the documentation and fix it.

- IE9-10 require explicit contexts to be passed to function pointers in certain cases (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622930%28v=vs.85%29.aspx). The `process.nextTick` implementation used for IE, which is based on `setImmediate`, was updated to accept and pass an explicit context to the callback.
- The implementation for DataTable.Row did not declare `self` to be a local variable, and IE9 wouldn't allow a new value to be assigned to it.

Updated the package to include a command line option that allows the user to specify whether or not they would like single line stack traces upon step failure.

Currently the stack traces that are output by the package in the event of a step failure are pretty large and make it a little more difficult to see what has failed. The changes I have made cut this trace down to a single line and shows only the line in the code that caused the step to fail.

The changes involved slight modifications to runtime, configuration, argument parser and step_definition.

I believe this addition would benefit others as it seems this issue has been flagged already.

Hi,
   I found an issue when running cucumberjs under windows.  It was not loading the support files before the step definitions.  This was because the regexp in the support_code_loader.js file was hard coded to a 'normal' file path.  Obviously, windows has to be different as always, so I have added a test for the windows platform and used backslashes in the regexp when this test passes.
I have since ran the unit tests which all pass

I could not think of a way to test this change in the unit test as I needed to spy on 'os.platform()' and return different values.  This would have needed to have been done before the code was loaded.

I have also tested it using my test suite (which contains a good 200+ steps) and it works on both linux (which it always did) and windows (which didn't work previously).

This pull request as you can see contains the required change.

Hopefully you can include this in the next release and I can remove my fork from github.

Thanks

Gary

Before this there was no way to control the output of error messages, resulting in a long stack trace. This allows the use of a custom error formatter using a --error_formatter= argument.

Right now it is possible to call callback fn multiple times in a step definition - this results with abnormal behavior - following/next steps are triggered for every callback invocation - this is simple check to prevent this + print to output that callback was called multiple times for some step.

I think that it improvement is useful during test development because async code based on events may trigger callback fn multiple times - it is not always obvious what is happening.
Fixed tags for scenarios in scenario outlines - i think that user should be able to tag scenario outline and by doing this all scenarios should inherit this tag.
Added separate method for stashedTags in outline scenarios,
Command line parameters for tag filters won't be applied to scenario outlines without this patch.

Based on the discussion in https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/27 i would like to propose this solution :
1) every time step is called ( invoked ) set a timeout with predefined value ( 30s ) , if callback in this step is not called ( success,fail or pending ) call callback.fail() with "Timeout" message - so it is invoked in the scope of the test - this way it has access to all details

2) Regarding configuration - there are two ways :
a) using CLI - add -t ( --timeout ) option with value in ms
b) when constructing new runner ( var runner = Cucumber(featureSource, supportCodeInitializer, options) ) - pass additional 'timeout' option with value in ms
Default value set to 30s is a save bet - in most cases nothing should take more then 30s - but since it is configurable it can be adjusted to the environment  

I believe that the same solution may be applied for hooks. 
I'm not particularly happy with configuration - please review it, i think that there may be better way to access Cucumber.Runtime.stepTimeoutValue...

Being able to define a timeout and get a feedback from the runner that some step has never finished is critical in my opinion - right now i developer may get false-positive results from the tests and it is harder to debug the tests and application code.

Please let me know if is valid solution in your opinion

It looks like bower dropped support for node.js v0.8 a couple of months ago: https://github.com/bower/bower/commit/cea53ddd1f17ee741f86f1ae4d3cc5e8c80fd7e2

cucumber-js uses an older version of Bower but I wonder if some of Bower's dependencies no longer support node.js v0.8/v0.6.  

Removing bower as a dev dependency makes the build go green.  I think Bower isn't normally needed for development of cucumber-js.  I think it was only needed the first time cucumber-js was registered with the Bower registry (http://bower.io/#registering-packages) which is a one off activity.  Would you be happy with removing Bower as a dependency?
Implemented CLI argument --report for specifying a file location to which the formatter output will be written.

This would give more freedom to the third-party extensions (which (just an example) may need to know total number of steps before scenarios start to execute) as well make events more consistent in respect to data access (*Features seem to be the only events lacking payload).

Thank you.
I've been using wkf's promise additions to cucumberjs, and merged in cucumber-js master's stuff yesterday. This should be a fastforward merge to add in these optional niceties.

A recent change in cucumber.js has caused the pretty formatter to always output a source uri before every feature and step:

Feature: some feature
        Scenario: I haven't done anything yet   # features\a.feature:2
          Given I have not defined this step    # features\a.feature:3

This caused our CI server to output a lot more text than necessary (the path names are very long).

This pull request allows you to change whether or not these source uris are printed out using the `--no-source` command line flag.

The pull request also includes cucumber tests for this new functionality under features/pretty_formatter.feature

Like other cucumber implementations, it would be nice to be able to run just a single scenario in a large feature file using the command line argument pattern featurefilename.feature:linenum.

This involved making sure any "expandPaths" calls could ignore, yet preserve, the line number suffix, so that once the feature file source is loaded, the parser has access to the scenario.getUri() with the specified line number (if any). Then an astFilter can simply include or exclude scenarios if a line number was passed.

I had to fix one unimplemented (mislabelled) step in cli_steps.js and also apply the patch in issue #120 / #123 because the stdout not being fully flushed causes the cli.features to fail.

Look forward to any feedback.

Cheers
Simon

Version 1.7.x of CoffeeScript requires that you register it before requiring .coffee files in node.

```
When requiring CoffeeScript files in Node you must now explicitly register the compiler. This can be done with require 'coffee-script/register' or CoffeeScript.register(). Also for configuration such as Mocha's, use coffee-script/register.
```

So, I have added the register method to the initialize method of support code loading and the error described in #153 goes away.

Given a big body of features and scenarios, it's nice to be able to partition the list of tests and run those pieces in parallel. One straightforward way to achieve this is: if there are `N` test runners, then the `i`-th runner only runs test scenario `j` if `(j % N) == i`.

This pull request is an implementation of a filter using the modular arithmetic logic described above. This is analogous to the tag filter which determines which scenarios to run based on tags passed at the command line. To invoke a segmented run of the tests, one runs:

`cucumber.js --parts 3 --remainder 0` in runner 0
`cucumber.js --parts 3 --remainder 1` in runner 1
`cucumber.js --parts 3 --remainder 2` in runner 2

Allows to determine scenario name and so make hooks more useful and
scenario-oriented.

*If a step was accessing the callback through the arguments object (instead of with a named argument) AND returned a 'promise like' object, then this code would incorrectly call then on the 'promise like' object, instead of waiting for the callback. This seemed rare enough to not really matter, but worth mentioning anyway.

JsonFormatter is the only formatter not using Cucumber.Listener.Formatter. Listener.Formatter add an option to define the logging callback which can be usefull. I needed to use the formatter without process.stdout in a browser so I added a new 'options' parameter used by Listener.Formatter. 'self' now inherit from Listener.Formatter instead of Listener.

This change is needed to use JsonFormatter in a browser.

Here's a way to get the step definition snippets in CoffeeScript syntax (raised in [issue #65](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/65)). I really wanted to use them, so thought I'd go ahead and try to patch.

I've removed the static properties from `Cucumber.SupportCode.StepDefinitionSnippetBuilder` and created new syntax behaviors `Cucumber.SupportCode.StepDefinitionSnippetBuilderSyntax.JavaScript` and `Cucumber.SupportCode.StepDefinitionSnippetBuilderSyntax.CoffeeScript` which will switch dependent on the `--coffee` CLI option.

To be honest, it's the first time I've used Jasmine properly, so you may think that what I've done could be improved.

Ta,
John

Of note:

Had to fix circular requirejs dependencies that broke cucumber in the browser in my previous pull request. Now everything looks like it's ok. Cucumber/Jasmime tests all pass. Tested the example server page. Tested in phantomjs with dojo toolkit.

Unfortunately, the way that jasmine requires a scope object to spy on a method, prevents you from requiring a dependency directly in the requirejs scope. So you have to require a level above you so that the tests can pass. But this gets you into a circular dependency situation. Thankfully, requirejs allows for a way to resolve this at module runtime by providing a synchronous version of require() after all modules have loaded.

Removing dependency on Browserify and underscore was necessary. The problem was that it tied cucumber-js to Node. You had to run a Node server. While making it possible to run in a browser, in order to do that Browserify defines it's own set of require/define functions a'la Node (strict CommonJS) in the browser. This makes it awkward to use cucumber with other JavaScript toolkits that already have their set of AMD require/define functions. For example, require.js is one package that defines the AMD functions. Dojo is another that defines the AMD functions (based largely on require.js and 100% compatible). jQuery is also compatible with AMD and requirejs. With this, now you can take cucumber-js and run it in any server with any number of javascript toolkits that support AMD.
Adds a pretty printer listener/formatter, updates the help text, and adds specs for the new formatter.

body: This adds a pretty formatter to cucumber-js. It makes some changes to the Core API to enable traversing from the feature object down to the steps with their step results. Tests for this are in another commit that will be part of another pull request.

- Addition of pretty printer.
- Make cucumber library callable in browser environment where require() and define() have already been defined in the require.js style. This makes it possible to inject cucumber-js in a page with Dojo, for example, in a headless browser (e.g. phantomjs) with pretty printed output to the console.

Had to fix circular requirejs dependencies that broke cucumber in the browser in my previous pull request. Now everything looks like it's ok. Cucumber/Jasmime tests all pass. Tested the example server page. Tested in phantomjs with dojo toolkit.

Unfortunately, the way that jasmine requires a scope object to spy on a method, prevents you from requiring a dependency directly in the requirejs scope. So you have to require a level above you so that the tests can pass. But this gets you into a circular dependency situation. Thankfully, requirejs allows for a way to resolve this at module runtime by providing a synchronous version of require() after all modules have loaded.

- Addition of pretty printer.
- Make cucumber library callable in browser environment where require() and define() have already been defined in the require.js style. This makes it possible to inject cucumber-js in a page with Dojo, for example, in a headless browser (e.g. phantomjs) with pretty printed output to the console.
